WE LOOK AT PETE, STANDING IN THE SNOW, TREES ALL AROUND H
AROUND HER, AS SHE STRUGGLES TO STAND.
BUMPERS. AN AMBULANCE IS PARKED BESIDE THEM.
FUCKING DO IT ASSHOLE, PULL YOUR
WE PULL HIGHER, UNTIL THE MOUNTAINS COME INTO VIEW, THE C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow lines whip beneath us. The faded blacktop is a gra blur as we chew road. To our left is an ocean of sage brush and dirty snow, sprawled out before the towering WIND RIVER MOUNTAIN RANG A PICK UP TRUCK makes its way down a deserted highway. On door is an OFFICIAL SEAL and the letters U.S.F.W.S.: THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. INT. PICK UP TRUCK -- CONTINUOUS. A MAN grips the steering wheel. Sips coffee from a travel mug. He’s around 40. Sunken cheeks. Mustache.  Cowboy hat on his head. Almost white when it was new -- sweat, dirt, and who knows what else, have stained the ha brown and robbed it of its shape. A fair description of the man as well. Through the windshield we see a dirt road that meets the black top. The truck slows, turns onto it. EXT. SAGEBRUSH PRAIRIE -- DAY. FIVE HUNDRED SHEEP wander through snow in a futile search something to eat. In the distance, we see: TWO COYOTES. They duck behind th sagebrush, then reappear seventy-five yards closer, only disappear again. Farther to the flock’s left, THREE MORE COYOTES approach trot. They see no need for stealth -- these sheep have nowhere to go ... The sheep spot the killers approaching and huddle into a tight circle -- with the rams forming an outer layer of protection. If coyotes could laugh, they would laugh at this. The two wary coyotes; however, make no attempt to approac They raise their noses to the air -- sucking in the wind’ secrets. And just like that, they disappear. The other three move eagerly toward their lunch. THUNDER SHAKES THE VERY EARTH. One of the coyotes is blown backwards, cart-wheeling thro the snow. The other two stop. MORE THUNDER. A second coyote is driven into the ground l he’s been hit with a giant hammer. The last coyote turns and runs for the safety of anywhere here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man, dressed completely in white, lays prone -- invis in the snow. A rifle pressed to his shoulder. He works th bolt -- chambers another round.  WE SEE THE LAST COYOTE THROUGH A RIFLE SCOPE. The cross-hairs find the back of the coyote’s head bounci in and out of view. The scope begins to move with it. The rifle invades the silence again. When the muzzle flash disappears, we see the coyote splayed out in the snow. In the distance, the two coyotes wise enough to never tru the scent of man crest a far rise, and drop out of view. The sheep shriek in terror as they run around in a giant, panicked, pointless circle. The man rises and walks toward the carnage he inflicted. The flock runs right toward the man, who doesn’t stop. Doesn’t even look in their direction. The flock almost runs into him before dividing and passin him on either side. They rejoin, and continue their silly circle -- all instinct for survival bred out of them. EXT. SAGEBRUSH PRAIRIE -- DAY. The man looks at the dead coyotes with no emotion. He rem a rope from a backpack. Begins looping the rope around th back feet of a coyote, then moves to another and does the same. All three are now tethered together and he begins the cho of dragging them through the snow and red dirt. He drags them past the flock, which stands idly by, panti like tired dogs. His dark eyes hold no joy. No sorrow either. This is not sport. This is his job. This is CORY LAMBERT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory warms his free hand against the truck’s vent. Grabs coffee. Takes a sip. The coffee’s cold. Doesn’t matter -- his first cold cup of coffee. He stares at the road. If t truck had a radio that worked, he’d turn it on.  EXT. BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT FIELD OFFICE -- DAY. BLM OFFICER TIM WINTER, late 30's, big coat, bigger cowbo hat, stands beside USFWS ENFORCEMENT AGENT DALE BERTRAM, early 30's. They stare at the coyotes in the bed of Corey truck.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Did you see Wyman’s sheep dogs near the flock?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Told me he had six dogs watching over it.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: He don’t have six dogs anymore. Those coyotes moved on that flock like they’ve been doing it all month.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Buggers are bad this year. We'll be lucky if there’s a flock of sheep standing come April. Tim looks to the STORM CLOUDS that loom over the WIND RIV MOUNTAIN RANGE like a reckoning.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After this storm, I want you up in a chopper. Those mutt’s will be easy to spot with a coat of fresh snow. When can your boy fly, Dale?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: We'll see what kind of wind follows the storm. Maybe Wednesday. He looks at Cory.

dialogues.speaker: DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got a call from BIA Police, the chief was asking for you. A mountain lion’s working through the flocks east of Boulder Flats. Tim can’t help but laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You’d think folks would learn this isn’t sheep country. They all laugh at that.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Tore up a horse and some weanlings too.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That sounds like wolves.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Chief says it’s a cat, and they ain't had no luck getting it. I offered Kenny and his hounds, but they don’t want a white man running around on the rez with a firearm.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: They don’t want a white man out there period. I’1l call him.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I forget you’re part Indian.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Well ... I’m Indian enough to do favors, but not enough to pull a check.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Be careful out there. Half those boys are tweaked out of their minds. Cory doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Shit, that junk’s everywhere now. I’m scared to let my daughter leave the house. As soon as Tim says it, he wishes he could have it back. Everyone looks to the ground. To the mountains. To the st hovering. Anywhere but Cory, who stares at the coyotes’ corpses in the bed of his truck. Lifeless eyes stare back

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Drop those off at Fish and Game.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yep. He climbs in his truck and starts it in one fluid motion. pulls toward the road as the coming storm inches closer.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CORY’S PICK UP -- LANDER, WYOMING -- DAY. Cory drives through the town of Lander. Feed stores, fast food, and a Wall Mart pass by his window. He turns on a s street and pulls up to a small house. Parks. Gets out. EXT. WILMA LAMBERT’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS. Cory walks up the driveway past a faded, Silver Subaru. Reaches the door. Rings the bell. The door opens and WILMA LAMBERT, 38, full blood Shoshoni gives Cory a terse smile. She was a beauty two kids and many heartaches ago, but ba food and cigarettes are winning the war against her looks Still, effort went into her hair, and make-up was delicat applied.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: You got blood on your shirt.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I was at work. She nods, but doesn’t approve.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Who was the victim today? Cory knows her well enough to sense her moods, and appare she’s in one right now.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Looks like it’s gonna be me. She stares at him. Her face goes from anger to pity to ti in an instant. She waves him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want some coffee? He doesn’t, but:

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Sure. Thank you. He steps in, removing his hat. INT. WILMA LAMBERT’S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS. It is exactly what you would expect from a prefab home ow by a woman with good taste and no money. The place is spotless. Mismatched Lazy Boys and outdated furniture are thoughtfully arranged. Wilma disappears into the kitchen, leaving Cory alone in living room. He stares at the ground. Fumbles with his hat. Looks at t ceiling fan. ... Gives up and turns his gaze toward the fireplace. Above the mantle is a 16x24, FRAMED YEARBOOK PHOTOGRAPH o TEENAGE GIRL. She wears a basketball uniform. Black hair neatly braided into long pig-tails. Big smile. Bright eye His eyes. Sage bundles, Sweetgrass braids, and an eagle feather are arranged around it. It is a shrine. Wilma returns. Hands him a mug. He nods his appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I gotta go to the Rez tomorrow, thought I’d take Casey by your folks. She winces at the word ‘Rez’, then nods at the word ‘folk

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Something killed a yearling in the pasture behind their house.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That's why I’m going.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Probably one of those Littlefeather demons. They stole two of Daddy’s calves last spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountain lion, wolf, or demon child, they want me to find it. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Don’t let Casey out of your sight on the Rez, okay?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I was gonna leave him with your folks while I scouted. Too cold to drag him through the snow.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. Cory seems to make eye contact with her for the first tim

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do. And I won't. Beat. Cory sips his coffee. Then yells down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: DAD                         OKAY! I’M COMING. Appearing in the hall and bumbling toward Cory is CASEY LAMBERT, 8 years old. Olive skin and short, black hair covered by a weathered cowboy hat very similar to Cory’s. Though the skin and hair are darker, this is clearly Cory son. The boy labors toward his dad with suitcase, sleeping bag coat, and BB gun in a noisy, clumsy, ball of energy.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What did I tell you about pointing that BB gun at people? Casey freezes. Drops everything but the gun.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Sorry dad.  iu.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Being careless won’t get you anywhere faster.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Put the BB gun in the truck then come back for the rest.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. He begins running for the door.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Don’t run with it. Slows to an urgent walk. Pushes through the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: I’1ll be back Monday afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Watch yourself on the road.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: He doesn’t need to be missing school to go chasing coyotes with you.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: We'll get all the chase out of our system tomorrow ... You be careful.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: This won’t be my first snow storm in a car. Beat. Cory walks over to Casey’s things.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let him. Needs to learn to do things for himself. Cory grabs his things anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I agree, but I’ve stood here as long as I care to. Hope the interview goes well in Jackson.  di.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Yep. We’ll see.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: If anyone was born to make a living talking on the phone ... She takes the jab as one of affection, which it was.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a good school over there. Good town. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: If I get the job, we’re gonna have to talk about his child support -- Jackson’s a lot more expensive.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Get the job. We’ll get the rest figured. You got my word. Whatever happened to these two, they are unified in their desire to find a better life for their son. He pushes the screen door open. Looks back at her.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take Togwotee Pass. Don’t go through Pinedale. Storm’s coming from the south. Wilma’s eyes go dark.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: You couldn’t drag me through Pinedale with a rope. I’1l never set foot in that town again. He nods without agreeing, then pushes through the door. INT. CORY’S PICK UP -- DAY. Casey looks at his father, then at the coming storm.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: She’s gonna be a bad one. Cory hides a smile at Casey’s attempt to speak like a man Looks at his son -- a miniature, if darker, version of hi Looks at his hat -- beaten and filthy, just like his.  12.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You just got that at Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: It’s taken a beating, just like a hat should.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Doing what? You've only had the thing two months.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: I’m in the 4-H barn three times a week. Cory draws in a breath to reprimand. Looks at his boy -- desperate to please -- and swallows it. Gives wisdom inst

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Life dirties things plenty fast on its own, don’t need any help from you. Casey stares at the floorboard. Gives a submissive nod as excitement of a weekend with dad drains from him. He look out the window as the outskirts of town fade into frozen fields. Cory regrets saying anything at all.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Casey looks up.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When we get home, I’1l help you dust that hat up the right way. Okay? The tiniest of smiles crosses Casey’s face. Through the windshield we see storm clouds, black as the coming night, push against the mountains that contain the EXT. CORY LAMBERT’S PLACE -- DUSK. Beside a small house is a corral. Four horses huddle together, asses to the wind, wishing like hell it was spr Cory and Casey emerge from an old barn carrying hay. Cory flips a latch and swings the gate open, snapping the hors from their stupor.  is. The horses head straight for Casey -- RIPPING HAY FROM HI BUNDLE. Cory tosses his hay bale in a trough, then turns back to Casey.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Push their nose when they rub up on you like that. Casey pushes one horse as another reaches over his head a grabs more hay, whipping Casey in the face when it does, knocking him down. Cory steps up and all the horses hurry toward the trough, like a high school fight breaking up when the principal arrives. Cory looks at his son, who has no hay left to hold. He si on the ground -- face, coat, and hat covered in shredded alfalfa and horse slobber.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Told’'ya I'd get that hat dirty.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: They got the height advantage on me is the deal.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: We can fix that. Cory smiles. Most kids would’ve been terrified, but Casey stood his ground. Cory walks up behind Casey, lifts him and sets him on a l colored mare that is far too busy eating to care about th boy now on her back.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember what I showed you?

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: But she’s eating.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You want that horse to be yours some day, prove it. Not to me, to her. Casey lets out a breath. Grabs a handful of mane, and pul back slightly. The mare raises her head, but doesn’t move  14. CORY (CONT’D) Put those boots into the front of her chest. He kicks into her. She bolts up. Casey grabs on tight. CORY (CONT’D) I didn’t say kick. Ask her before you tell her. Just press your boots into her chest. Gentle. He does, and the mare backs up.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ease up on the mane, and give her a little nudge in the ribs. He does. The mare obeys, and moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wherever you look is where she goes. Take her to the gate. Casey stares at the gate with the focus of a surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get alongside and open it. Casey sends cues through his feet and negotiates the mare parallel to the fence. He reaches down to the latch. Casey wrestles with the latch his father flipped without effort. He struggles. CORY (CONT’D) Freezes up quick, don’t it ... Give it a good hit. Casey curls his fist and pounds the lever. The gate swing open. Cory pulls Casey off and sets him on the ground, fa the mare.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let her know you. Casey stands in front of her. The mare inches closer, pressing her nostril to Casey’s nose, inhaling his exhale breath.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put a hand to her face. Gentle, like a friend.  io. He does. Then looks back at his father, all smiles once again.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: That was pretty cowboy, huh.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No, son. That was Arapahoe. Cory closes the gate and they walk to the little house as mare hangs her head over the fence, watching the boy -- forgetting the meal so important a moment ago. INT. CORY’S HOUSE -- NIGHT. Cory and Casey sit on the couch. Casey eats a sandwich an stares at the TV. Cory looks over A TOPO MAP as he speaks the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m looking at it. There’s drill rigs over there, lions don’t like the noise ... You sure it’s something and not somebody? ... Alright, I’11 check it out in the morning. If you got lions, I’m gonna have to bring Kenny’s hounds in to run ‘em ... Name a Indian with lion hounds and I’1l use him. Call you if I find anything. Cory hangs up. Looks at his son, lost in the television. Little mouth chewing little bites, stopping for a little of soda. Cory watches him. Smiles. Sits back quietly. The smile disappears. Worry replaces it. Above the fireplace is the same photograph of a teenage g dressed to shoot hoops, though much smaller. Cory stares the photo, then back to his son -- who is staring right a him. Casey smiles, then returns to the TV. Cory rubs his eyes. Pinches the bridge of his nose. Hard. Forcing emotion to retreat to wherever emotion comes from

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Lo. INT. CORY LAMBERT’S HOUSE -- CASEY’S BEDROOM -- NIGHT. The door creaks open. A shadow slinks in. Sits on the edg the bed. A hand reaches out and rests gently on Casey’s chest.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Hey. The sheets move a little.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. Wake up, son. We gotta go. Casey bolts upright.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: I’M UP. The shadow rises, walks to the door. Turns on the light.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I'm making breakfast. Get dressed. We gotta feed the horses. Casey rubs furiously at his eyes and yawns.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Waiting on you.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (Smiles)Yeah ... I can see that. Cory walks out as Casey rises, shaking off the night.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CORY’S PICK UP -- PRE-DAWN. Cory sips coffee. As they drive down the highway, PRONGHO ANTELOPE walk parallel to the road. Following a path carv into these plains before man sparked his first fire. INT. CORY’S PICK UP -- DAWN. The sun has crested the horizon behind us. Ahead of us -- Wind River mountains and the storm clouds that gather abo them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come the clouds just sit there? Why don’t they dump their snow and get it over with?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Mountains hold the clouds back with the winds that blows between ‘em. Makes a sort of suction. Sometimes they can suck the storm right out of the clouds. Sometimes they just make it worse, cuz a big storm will sit there and gather strength from the winds that hold it back ... Our ancestors believed the storms hold the spirits of vengeance, and the mountains are our protector. But when enough evil lives in our people, the mountains free the storm to punish the demons among us.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: That what you believe? Cory smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sometimes. Up ahead, we see a small, log cabin with a barn even wors off than Cory’s. TWO HORSES run and kick at the dropping pressure and the storm behind it. Cory drives up and park The front door is already open. An Indian man in his 70's stands in long johns and boots with no regard for the sub zero temperature. This is DAN CROWHEART, Casey’s grandfat

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Re: the horses) Sense the storm.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: Yep. That’s my cue to stick ‘em in the barn. But with a lion about, I don’t want ‘em stuck in a open stall. They gonna have to make their peace with the storm. (Opening his arms) Come here, grandson.  1d. Casey is already doing that. He runs to him and the old m lifts him with a strength we didn’t credit him with havin CROWHEART (CONT’D) You’re Grandma made fry bread. You have breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Just eggs.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: Go get some then. Casey disappears inside. Crowheart looks to Cory. CROWHEART (CONT’D) Hau, Munape.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: Police chief called you to hunt the lion, eh?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: He called me to hunt something. You lost a steer?

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: I‘1l show you where. It’s a lion. He grabs a coat from a rack and steps outside. They walk behind the house, past the horses and toward a large, fen field completely covered in snow. CROWHEART (CONT’D) How’s Wilma?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Headed to a job interview in Jackson. Some hotel.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: Jackson Hole. Gonna go live with the millionaires.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about, billionaires chased out the millionaires years ago. Crowheart looks back as he walks and smiles.  iy.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: Save your money. When the wolves start eating their Golden Retrievers, that land’s gonna go for pennies on the dollar. Cory laughs. Crowheart stops. THE SNOW IS STAINED RED. Ju beyond is the body of a young steer. Crowheart stands ove and points to tracks in the hard snow. CROWHEART (CONT’D) Tell me what that is. Cory lowers himself to it. Must admit --

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That’s a lion. Cory follows the tracks. Crowheart stays put, watching. Fifty yards away Cory stops. Looks back at Crowheart.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: There’s two. He follows the tracks farther.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Three. She’s got both of last year’s kits with her. They chased your steer around for a while, I bet.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: That’s what the tracks say. Cory walks back toward him.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: She's teaching them to hunt. And she’s teaching ‘em on livestock ... (Shakes his head) She just got her whole family killed. Cory looks toward the mountains. From here, they tower ov us like a canyon wall.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re tucked up there somewhere. I'll go have a look ... You mind watching Casey for a few hours? Crowheart smiles.  ZU.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: You never have to ask that.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Got gas in your snowmobile? EXT. WIND RIVER RESERVATION -- DAY. Cory drives a snowmobile over the frozen ground, followin the tracks. He is far from the cabin. Far from anything. mountains are so close, you could almost reach out and to them. To the left, the prairie is broken with GAS DRILL A GAS DRILL, all jutting eighty-feet into the air like gian steel darts fired into the earth. Cory slows, sees something he snowmobile. Looks down. We do HUMAN FOOTPRINTS IN THE SNOW. THE GROUND AROUND THEM. Cory steps off the snowmobile print -- knows instantly this didn’t expect. Stops the too.

dialogues.speaker: BAREFOOT. FROZEN BLOOD STAINING
dialogues.text: and places his hand against the person was not large. He checks his pistol and his rifle, making sure both are loaded, removes the WHITE CAMO from his backpack. Puts it Follows the tracks on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance, he is invisible. It is as though the sno itself stood up and walked. WE WALK BEHIND HIM NOW. The mountains are a hundred yards from him. Pine trees lo over the snow. The clouds cast a shadow that is visible j fifty yards ahead. Cory studies the ground. Takes two more steps, then stops IN FRONT OF HIM IS A PERFECT IMPRINT OF THE GIRL. As thou she laid down and made a bloody snow-angel. We see where she stood up and stumbled toward a small arr just ahead. Cory slings the rifle over his shoulder slowly. Silently. Pulls out his RUGER BLACKHAWK PISTOL. He hides the pistol under his coat, and cocks the hammer no noise.  21. He raises the pistol to eye level and moves forward. Wher he looks -- the pistol points. He crests the little arroy and stares down. At first he sees nothing. Then -- A HAND. REACHING FROM T SNOW. He looks around. Nothing. He looks at the ground. No trac except those of the girl. He moves to the hand. Gently brushes the snow away. THE RUNNING GIRL’S FACE STARES BACK. Frozen in a constipated moan. Blood frozen to her face. Blood mixed with the snow ice around her. Cory stares at her -- almost as frozen as she is. His breath leaves him -- but not from the sight of a dead body. He’s seen plenty in his day. This is a body he know A snowflake falls. Then another. Takes off his back pack, pulls out a two-way radio. Turns to channel 16 -- the emergency channel -- and speaks with hollow voice.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I need emergency assistance. Repeat. Emergency assistance requested ... Come back? Static crackles, then a voice filters through.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fremont County Sheriff's office. What’s your emergency.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I found a body on the Wind River Indian Reservation west of Boulder Flats, I need Tribal Police to respond to the following location... We pull back and snow begins to fall. We pull back farthe and Cory fades as the snow falls faster. A STRONG WIND pushes the snowflakes horizontal -- it is snowing sideways. The storm breaks free from the mountains’ grasp with a vengeful howl -- ready to punish this land and her people all the evil they’ve done.  ZZ. EXT. DAN CROWHEART’S CABIN -— DAY. Cory stands on the little porch with TRIBAL POLICE CHIEF SHOYO, 50, kind, round face and large, heavy frame. They watch the storm throw snow at the earth like shrapne Barely visible to the left of the house are THREE TRIBAL

dialogues.speaker: BUMPERS. AN AMBULANCE IS PARKED BESIDE THEM.
dialogues.text: Two snowmobiles sit in front of the house. Ben lights a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: FBI’s taking a while, eh.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Road’s bad out of Riverton. I hate to move her before they’ve had a look, but I’m not gonna try to pull her out after dark. We gotta get this show on the road. Cory steps out into the snow. Kicks at it with his boot.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: We're losing the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: This ain’t letting up. Not for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Oughta let me follow ‘em while I still can.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Can’t have you out there without the FBI’s okay, Cory. Cory looks back to the men on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You call her folks yet, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I want to get her to Lander first. It looks like Natalie, but I don’t want to call the wrong person. Not about this. Beat.  Z5e

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: It’s Natalie. We look out from the porch and can barely make out -- A B SUV, crawling through the snow on the main road.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s your Feds. INT. BLACK SUV -- CONTINUOUS. FBI AGENT JANE BANNER, 28, struggles to see through the s as her GPS directs her.

dialogues.speaker: GPS
dialogues.text: In seventy-five feet, turn right.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: ... Where?!

dialogues.speaker: GPS
dialogues.text: Turn right ... Turn right.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Where do you want me to turn right?? WHERE!!! Dirty-blonde hair falls over a pretty face as she peers closer to the windshield in an attempt to see where the h she’s supposed to go. EXT. DAN CROWHEART’S CABIN -- PORCH -- DAY. Dan, Ben, and Cory look at the SUV -- barely visible thro the storm -- PULL TO A STOP on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: What are these fools doing?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Can’t see the road. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We don’t have time for this.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I’ll go get ‘em. Cory walks to his snowmobile.  24. INT. JANE’S SUV -- CONT. She can barely make out the house a quarter-mile away, an the police vehicles -- white themselves -- are completely invisible. Jane pulls a ROAD ATLAS out and studies it. Looks back ou the window. Hears what sounds like the whine of a CHAIN SAW. Cory appears from the snow like a wraith, pulls up beside Jane's window. Knocks on it. No idea a gun is now pointed him on the other side of the vehicle’s door. She cracks the window, leery.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You FBI?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: ++. You Tribal Police?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No. But I’1l take you to them. This thing in four-wheel drive?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Alright, follow me. Cory whips the snowmobile around, spewing snow, then driv toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: GPS
dialogues.text: In fifty feet -- Jane pounds the power button with her fist.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Shut up. Jane puts the SUV in gear and follows. The police vehicle come into view, as does Ben, standing on the porch. His uniform is her first evidence this isn’t an ambush. Cory already parked and is walking back to the protection of t overhang. She slams the SUV in park and opens the vehicle door.  EXT. DAN CROWHEART’S CABIN -- CONT. 22. She tosses a coat over a business suit as she stumbles to them in the shin-deep snow.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m Jane Banner.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Is it just you? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Just me.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Ben Shoyo. I’m Tribal Police Chief. This is Cory Lambert, works for US Fish and Wildlife. He found the body. This is his father-in-law, Dan. He don’t do nuthin’.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: We got the same job, eh?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well. Sorry to meet under these circumstances. (To Cory) You wanna show me body? The men don’t move, just exchange bewildered looks. Jane shivers, hands jammed in her pockets. A half-inch of snow building on her shoulders and the top of her head.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be rude, but I’m freezing my ass off here, so...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s gonna get a lot worse if you go out there dressed like that.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm a big girl. Thank you. Cory steps to her.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Body’s a ten mile drive by snowmobile. You’d be dead before we got there.  Zo. She looks away from his dark, intense eyes. Feels a littl silly as she shivers in place.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I was in court in Riverton when I got the call to come here. This is what I have --

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You should have a winter-gear bag in the back there --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: This isn’t a government vehicle, it’s a rental. I flew in from Denver. I’m just the closest agent to the scene ... You don’t think I can make it like this? She is already shivering to the point it’s affecting her speech.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Come inside. We'll get you fixed up. He points toward the cabin. Ben extends a hand to her as reaches the first step. Crowheart has her elbow by the ti she’s on the porch. It is clear none of these men think s will live five minutes out here. She should be grateful. She isn’t. Pride makes her shake of the men cradling her like a wounded bird. She walks in the house. Ben looks at Cory, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: See what they send us? INT. CROWHEART’S CABIN -- BEDROOM -- A LITTLE LATER. The humiliation continues as ALICE CROWHEART, 64, a hundr pounds overweight, and fierce eyes, watches Jane pull a p of thermal underwear over her g-string.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Thermals can make underwear wedge up your bottom, but I guess yours are already there. Jane’s smart enough to not respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, these should fit. You’re skinny.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Alice hands her a pair of jeans. They’re a little tight, they’1l do. She climbs into a pair of COVERALLS. Alice hands her a wool skull cap.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You got gloves? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No. Alice shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Goodness. What were they thinking sending you here. Aside from her cheeks, virtually all of Jane is covered. looks at herself in the mirror -- feels ridiculous. Alice looks too. Covers her mouth with her hand. Looks li she may cry, then turns back to the bed. Starts folding t rejects.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you. While looking down, focused on her folding --

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You return them the minute you get back. They ain’t a gift. Alice turns and looks right at her.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: .-. Of course. Jane walks out to the living room -- all the men waiting her. Notices Casey.  2B.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m ... Bundled. Let’s go. Casey grabs his coat, pulls it on.

dialogues.speaker: CROWHEART
dialogues.text: You're gonna stay with me, young buck. Casey looks up at his father. Cory kneels down. Looks int his eyes as his hand gently cups the back of Casey’s neck

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: A couple more hours, son. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: A couple. This is our day.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I promise. Casey seems to tighten and deflate at the same time, as h father rises and walks to the door. Ben looks outside.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It ain’t letting up. Cory looks, then turns back to Jane.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: It’s ten below outside. You leave that pride on the porch and hug me like your prom date, understood? Jane is so offended she almost falls backwards.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m the highest ranking law enforcement officer for three hundred miles in any direction. Don’t ever tell me what to do again. Steps closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to insult you, just making sure there’s only one girl froze to death out there today. She turns from him and walks out into the storm.  29. EXT. SAGEBRUSH PRAIRIE -- DAY. Jane sits behind Cory on the snowmobile. They race throug the white at 60 miles-per-hour. Jane presses her face into the back of this stranger -- h hands tucked under his ass -- as she experiences cold ina manner unexplainable to those who haven’t endured it. Up ahead, we see FOUR POLICE SNOWMOBILES, and FOUR OFFICE huddling around a MOBILE PROPANE HEATER. TWO EMT’S huddle beside the body. Cory and Ben park. Walk toward them. Cory doesn’t wait fo Jane to start asking questions.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I picked up her tracks about 300 meters to the south. Jane nods as she struggles to shake off the bone-breaking cold. They walk past the officers to NATALIE HANSON’S BODY, and EMT holding a HEAT GUN -- basically a very powerful hair dryer -- that he waves along Natalie’s body where it meet the ice that holds her. Jane kneels next to her.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Calls back to Ben)Got a positive

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Not positive, no. Cory, and three of the officers say in unison:

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: It’s Natalie Hanson.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Haven't found any identification, no one from the family has identified the body, but ...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: We'll call that positive for now. She live close?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Fort Wakashie. North a ways.  DU.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What’s ‘a ways’?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Thirty minute drive.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Okay, she didn’t run from home. Jane studies the gash. Touches the body.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s frozen solid. She looks back at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No one reported her missing? Her parents?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No. She takes that in.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Makes the parents rather suspect. No one likes the sound of that, but they all hold their tongues. Jane notices dried blood that has soaked and frozen to th crotch of her sweatpants. Notices her bare feet.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Softly) Who did this to you, honey? As out of place as Jane is in the wild, and this may very well be her first murder scene -- she ignores the cold an focuses. Patient. Observant. She looks up at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How experienced is your medical examiner? The irony of this girl asking who’s experienced ...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: He stays busy.  SL.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Order a rape kit, When he’s done with his prelim, I want her sent to Cheyenne. Make sure her belongings go with her. I need them tested. I’m listing this as a homicide. One of the officers can’t help but mumble --

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Gee, you think? Jane stands, looks over the land -- covered in a foot of fresh powder. With more falling.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: We're not going to find the attack site if it’s out in the open. Not till spring, anyway. She turns to Cory.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How well do you know this land?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Like it’s my job. Which it is.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Anywhere she could have been running from? Anything close?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Nearest homes are seven or eight miles southeast.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Sam Littlefeather’s house is out there.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Those boys are worth looking into.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m no survivalist, but that’s too far to run in the snow -- she’s dressed no better than I was and I almost froze to death in your front yard.  32.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You’re not from here.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: There’s no structures closer?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Drill rigs maybe five miles from here. There’s trailers for the workers. But they shut it down in the winter.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: So why would a teenage girl be out here?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Kids come out here on snowmobiles. Have a big party out here in the snow.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Not barefoot they don’t. (To Cory) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Only thing I can tell you about is the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That’s the only thing we've got. Cory looks at her for a moment, walks a few feet, begins kicking snow -- making a little clearing. He kneels into the snow and very delicately begins using hands, then leans over and blows the snow away.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Look here. She leans over him. NATALIE’S FOOT PRINT AND FROZEN BLOOD NOW MIXED WITH SNOW is visible. CORY (CONT’D) See how the toes twist out? And the front of the track is deeper than the back -- almost no imprint of the heel?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yeah.  33e

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: She was running. He stands. Points to Natalie’s body thirty yards away. CORY (CONT’D) She ran until she dropped. There’s a spot over here where she fell ... Cory walks to the bloody snow angel.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A pool of blood where her face hit. Gets down to twenty below out here at night. You breathe that cold air deep in your lungs -- like when you're running, it’ll freeze em. Lungs fill up with blood, you start coughing it up. He points to the impression of her face and the pool of blood. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wherever she came from, she ran all the way here. Her lungs burst and she curled up under that tree. She didn’t freeze to death ... She drowned.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How far could someone run barefoot out here? He looks out over the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I seen tourists freeze to death in these mountains when it was barely 40 degrees ... I seen a fur trader caught in his own trap, drag himself six miles to a forest service cabin and radio for help. In the dead of winter ... There ain’t no gauge for the will to live. Some have it. Plenty don’t +. I knew this girl. She was a fighter. However far we think she ran, my guess is she ran farther. Cory looks east.  34.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got to get back to my son. I promised him a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Would you be willing to help me? I mean, I can’t ... Hell, I couldn’t find the way back to my car. I don’t know how to investigate this without ...(She turns to Ben) Can I borrow him for a few days?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: He don’t work for me. (To Cory) You got a lion to kill, don’t forget.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: There’s three of ‘em. And I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: ... What do you do for the Forest Service?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I’m a hunter.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: «+. A lion hunter??

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I hunt predators. She looks back at the police officers trying to free Natalie’s corpse from a frozen land intent on keeping her

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Good. Come hunt one for me. WE PUSH IN CLOSER. Past the officers. Past the heat gun. We rest on her face watching as she slowly thaws. Watching the ice that seale her eyes begin to melt and run down her cheeks like tears Cory looks at her. Says, very softly --

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Okay.  3D. INT. JANE’S SUV -- NIGHT. SNOW pounds the windshield as the wipers work frantically remove it. Snow swarms in the headlights like locust. Jane leans forward, chin almost resting on the steering wheel, straining to see the road.

dialogues.speaker: GPS
dialogues.text: In half a mile, turn left on East Main Street. The GPS may be right, but there is no way to know -- Jane can’t see ten feet in front of her. She slows down even more -- barely going 30. Turns on her hazards ...

dialogues.speaker: GPS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In three hundred feet, turn left on East Main Street. She slows a little more, but still sees nothing -- no roa Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GPS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Turn left. Turn left. She looks to the left, then back to her right -- A TRUCK HORN BLARES. She slams on her brakes and begins sliding as a SEMI whip by, mere feet from her bumper. She slides to a stop in the middle of the intersection, n facing the direction of the Semi. She struggles to slow her beating heart as she watches th brake lights of the truck that almost killed her. The TRUCK DRIVER gets out, runs back to her. She rolls he window down.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I can’t see anything.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: IF YOU DON’T KNOW HOW TO DRIVE IN THIS YOU SHOULDN’T BE ON THE ROAD.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Who the hell knows how to drive in this??  30.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: Pull up behind me and follow me close. Don’t slam your brakes. Stay in second gear -- and you pull your ass into the first motel we come to.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That’s where I’m headed anyway.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: Well I guess it’s your goddam lucky day. He turns and runs through the storm back to his truck. Sh rolls up her window.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (To no one) I’m really sorry we never had blizzards in FUCKING FLORIDA!!! I’d like to see one of you bastards in a hurricane. He begins slowly moving forward. Mad as she is -- she obe and pulls up right behind him. EXT. SILVER SPUR LODGE -- LANDER, WYOMING -- NIGHT. The parking lot is completely empty and covered with snow The truck driver points out his window at the motel -- wi gesturing for her to go there. Jane turns into the lot, slamming the curb, and spinning wheels in a furious attempt to reach the safety of the covered entrance. She parks. Draws in a deep breath, opens the door and ste into the fury of the storm. INT. SILVER SPUR LODGE -- LANDER, WYOMING -- NIGHT. The decor is old west meets late 80’s -- wagon wheels, bl leather couches, and watercolors of mountains, cowboys, a horses. Behind the counter is INGRED, late 30’s, horribly obese, watching some version of CSI on a small TV. Jane approach the counter.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: You look a little frazzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a storm out there.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Yeah, you could've picked a better day to travel.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Could I get a room?

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: How many nights?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. A week, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Smoking?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Pets?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: If you have a pet, now’s the time to tell me -- a whining dog at 3am puts you both back in the storm.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No pets. Ingred slides over a large index card.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Mastercard, Visa or cash. Fill out your home address and vehicle information. I need to make a copy of your license. Jane lays her FBI ID and badge out.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Do you give a government discount?

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Government’s never given me one.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: --. So that’s a no.  3B.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: And how, lady. Jane nods as she sets her credit card and license on the counter. Ingred takes them, runs the card. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You here about that girl they just found?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How do you know about that?

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Small town(reading off the ID), Jane. Another Indian girl, I’m sure. Jane doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There ain’t gonna be a meth problem on the reservation much longer cuz there ain’t gonna be any Indians left to do it. Killing their babies faster than they can make new ones.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You have kids?

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Two sons. Oldest graduates in June.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Is meth a problem here?

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Girls and algebra’s my boy’s only problems. Can’t speak for no one else’s kids. Jane swipes her room key.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Is the room far?

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Put you in the first one out the door to the left. You can leave your car under the awning till morning.  Sy.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: INGRED
dialogues.text: Didn't do it to be nice. I got tulip bulbs in planters out there, and I need you running over ‘em like I need another hemorrhoid. With that Ingred climbs back on her stool and returns to TV. Jane turns and heads for the door. INT. CORY LAMBERT’S HOUSE -- NIGHT. Cory sits at his dining room table. A CENTERFIRE CARTRIDG RELOADER in front of him. Beside him is a MARLIN GUIDE GU a stainless steel, lever-action rifle chambered in .45-70 is a rifle for stopping bears. When they are running righ you. On a small scale he weighs bullets, choosing only those t weigh exactly 540 grains. He seats a rifle casing in the reloader, places a bullet in the machine’s teeth, pulls a lever. When he returns the lever upright, he has a fully formed bullet, almost four inches long.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad? Cory looks up. Casey stands in long johns -- hair messed sleep and a sheepish look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Thought you were sleeping. Casey looks at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: (Small) Had a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Bout what? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Who was she?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Come over here.  4uU. Casey shuffles over and sits at the table.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Want a glass of milk?

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: No. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: She's just a girl. Lost her way in the snow. Casey looks at the reloader and the gun resting against t table.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Work. Cory seats another rifle casing.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Did she die like Emily?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: She died from the cold.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: So she died like Emily. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yeah, son. I’m afraid she did. Cory pushes back from the table. Sets the rifle on the ta Pulls his son onto his lap.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Is that for the lion?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I’m doing some work for the government this week. It’s for that.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: It's a grizzly, isn’t it.  41.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what it is yet. But I’m gonna try and figure it out ... You wanna go back to bed?

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: No. Can I sleep with you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I ain’t going to bed for a while. Casey nods as if that wasn’t an answer he had considered.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You wanna curl up on the sofa, and I‘1l take you back with me when I’m done?

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Okay. Casey slips off his dad’s lap, crawls on the couch, and disappears under a blanket. Cory returns to his reloader, and the chore of fashioning death, half an ounce at a time. EXT. CORY LAMBERT’S HOUSE -- DAWN. We watch from across the road as Cory walks toward the ba Casey running behind. Sunlight bounces off the snow. The storm has passed. Blue skies above. We watch them disappear into the barn. Watch the horses p against the gate, unable to go another minute without the breakfast. INT. CORY’S PICK UP -- DAY. Casey holds his hands up to the heat vents. Cory looks at son, wearing his filthy, little cowboy hat.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What’s the test?

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: We're studying the presidents.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What about ‘em, birthdays?  42.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: No. The ones on money. Do you know who’s on the fifty dollar bill? Cory thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: President Grant.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That a fact.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Yep. Know who’s on the hundred dollar bill ... Ben Franklin?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: «+. I don’t think he was president.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: He got his face on money, I guess he’s the president of something. How bout a twenty dollar bill?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You know son, most of my experience has been with the George Washington and Abraham Lincoln variety.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: That’s the one dollar bill and the five.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Those I know. Cory pulls up in front of the elementary school.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Are you picking me up?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Your mom. Unless the road from Jackson's too bad, then it’1l be me.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: I hope the roads are bad.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You don’t ever wish that, son.  45. He doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I’1ll see you Thursday. Then you’re mine for a week. Casey smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Thursday. Casey opens the door. Steps out.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Good luck on that test.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: I love you, dad. Casey closes the door before Cory gets to say it back. Ca runs toward the school through a foot of snow. Cory watches the boy until he steps through the doors and they close behind him. Puts the truck in gear. Cory’s fac hardens -- he is a hunter again. INT. FREMONT COUNTY CORONER'S OFFICE -- NIGHT. Jane walks down a dim, grey hallway. Ben leans against th wall, sipping coffee.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I see you found town okay.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Barely. Did the family identify her?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: They give you a reason for not reporting her missing?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Got a boyfriend she stayed with some. Didn’t think anything of it. «+. She was eighteen. Free to do what she wanted.  44a,

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Gonna need to talk to the boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We'll get to that. Ben begins to push the exam room door open, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ever done this before?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Observed an autopsy? Come on ... No -.. Is it that obvious?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Anyone who tells you they get easier is a goddam liar. Let’s get it over with. They push through the doors. INT. EXAM ROOM -- CORONER'S OFFICE -- CONT. On a steel table is Natalie. Naked. Chest sawed open like gutted deer. Jane pretends like it doesn’t weaken her kne Ben walks toward the body, no attempt to hide his unease toward this awful part of his job. A man, dressed in scrubs, runs a centrifuge along a far w

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Randy, you’re on a clock. I’ve got about five minutes of this in me, so let’s go. DR. RANDY WHITEHURST turns and walks to the body.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: I'll be quick. (Nods to Jane) Good morning, Randy Whitehurst, I’m the medical examiner. Jane wants to look anywhere but the body or the man that her in half.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Uh huh. I’m Agent Banner.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you, yes. I’m FBI. He studies her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: This your first autopsy? How the fuck does everyone know that?

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, gotta have a first.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s my first on an investigation, but ... I am trained for this, so everyone just ... Can we get to it, please?

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am. As you see here, she suffered a deep laceration along her brow line. He points at each act of violence. Waits for nods from bo Jane and Ben before moving on.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Two separated ribs. Frost bite in both feet up through her ankles, frost bite on her nose and her left hand -- the frost bite on her feet is stage four, you can tell by the blueing here, you see that?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: Vaginal wall is torn. The damage on multiple sides of the wall at different depths indicates penetration by different individuals, and the bite marks along her neck and on the left nipple have distinct measurements --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: So there were two assailants.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: At least ... I swabbed her and sent the samples by courier to Cheyenne. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We should have DNA results in a week or so, but I will state in my report: sexual assault by multiple offenders. Jane has found herself next to Natalie’s head, can’t help gently stroke her hair as though reminding herself this carcass had a soul.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t touch her -- I haven’t combed her hair for forensics yet.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What are you listing as the cause of death?

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: You're not going to like it -- she died from a pulmonary hemorrhage. When sub-zero air is drawn into lungs, it can cause the alveoli -- the tiny sacs in the lungs -- to burst. Fluid builds in the lungs, and if the air is cold enough, liquid in the lungs will crystallize. Ultimately, the victim either freezes from the inside out, or they drown in their own blood -.. That’s the cause of death in this instance. Jane thinks. Cory was right. Then she realizes --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You're not listing this as a homicide?

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: Can't.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: But ... You have to factor in the circumstances. She was raped. Repeatedly. Beaten. And then --

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: Look, circumstances is your field, not mine. Let me show you, come here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t need it explained -- I need to find whoever chased her to death in this frozen hell and put them in prison, and not calling this a... She walks a lap around the room, calming herself, comes b to where she started.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: This is very prosecutable as a murder -- clearly she wouldn’t have been running through the snow if she hadn’t been attacked, but I can’t list the cause of death as a homicide.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The only way I can get an FBI team to the reservation is if it’s listed as a homicide. I’m not here to solve this, I’m here to obtain a cause of death and have someone sent here who can --

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: Look, present the rape, present the assault and I’m sure --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Those aren't federal crimes! Those crimes fall to the Bureau of Indian Affairs and ... Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: You keep saying sorry, but you keep doing it. She looks at Ben, eyes begging for an alternative.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m used to no help.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You have six officers on your entire force -- to cover an area the size of Rhode Island. No offense, but this will have to curl up in your lap for you to solve it. He does take offense, but also knows it’s true.  45.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WHITEHURST
dialogues.text: We all know it’s a murder. Have a US Attorney sign off on it. I’m happy to corroborate that, I just can’t put it on the death certificate. She walks off, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you. She pushes through the double doors to the hall. Ben walk out after her. She leans against the wall, looking at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I appreciate your passion. Not the usual response from Feds ... But Randy’s on our side -- She turns to him, fierce.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: As soon as my supervisor sees this he’s going to want me back in Denver. Not that I’m much help, but «+. I’m all you’re going to get. We have no time ... What’s that hunter’s phone number? INT. CORY’S PICK UP -- DAY. Cory moves through the reservation town of Wind River. It none of Lander’s conveniences -- no 7-11’s, no motels, no chain restaurants. Every structure looks wind-bleached and buckling from the weight of snow on the roofs. Cory’s cellphone rings.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Hello. EXT. TROUT CREEK ROAD -- CONT. We watch Cory’s truck -- pulling a small flat-bed trailer carrying a snowmobile -- slow down, make a three-point tu in the middle of the road, and head off the other way.  49. INT. HANSON HOME -- FORT WASHAKIE, WYOMING -- DAY. We are inside a house that screams poverty. Furniture is and broken to the point of barely being functional. Faux- siding of the manufactured home is fraying at the edges. Still, extreme care has been given to make it into a home Photos of Natalie and a handsome TEENAGE BOY are pasted o every wall. We hear Ben’s voice as we look over the home.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So you never met him.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And she never talked about him?

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Not to me. The man’s voice is soft, deep, almost soothing. As we pus on a photo of Natalie and the handsome young man, who is clearly her brother, we hear --

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why would you let her stay with a Man you’ve never met. A man whose name you don’t even know. I look around, see all these photos --

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She was an adult.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Barely. We see the man now -- Natalie’s father, MARTIN HANSON, 40 every bit of 6’2”. Long, black hair pulled in a braided p tail. Dark, heavy face. But those eyes -- a hawk’s eyes. warrior’s eyes. Which are burning into Jane. He looks at

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Wyuksa psi wasichu.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: .«-. It’s not good. She looks at the big man, apologizing without backing dow  Du.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don’t mean to offend you. I’m trying to understand the dynamic, Mr. Hanson. I’m trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Why is it whenever you people try to help, it starts with insults. He steps toward her, furious eyes and all. She resists th temptation to draw her weapon.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know why she wouldn’t tell me. But she was eighteen. I chose to trust her. I chose wrong. He looks her over.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How about your wife, did your daughter talk to her?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Do you talk to your mother? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It’s Annie? Is she here?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: She’s in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'd like to speak to her. His hawk eyes narrow. He says, almost like a dare --

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Be my guest.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you. (Points down the hall) Bedroom this way?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Jane. Ben shakes his head ‘no’.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (To Martin) You don’t mind?  Die

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hey, you don’t need my permission. You're an adult. Barely. Point made. She walks down the hall. Comes to a closed do Knocks softly. No answer. She opens the door and sees -- ANNIE HANSON is 50, heavy, and COVERED IN BLOOD. She sits the edge of her bed, sobbing, mumbling, and rocking back forth gripping a KITCHEN KNIFE. Cuts run up and down her arms. She never notices the open door. Jane doesn’t give a chance to -- she closes the door quickly. Jane stands a moment in the hall -- she is in no way prep to navigate this world, and she knows it. She dreads walk to the living room and facing Martin, but does it anyway. When she reaches the living room, Martin stares hell at h She has it coming.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. There is a knock at the door. Martin opens it. It’s Cory. The two men stare at each other. Don’t speak. Martin’s li tighten. Cory gives him a sad smile. Martin’s tight lips begin to quiver. Cory steps back onto the porch. Martin follows him. Cory kicks the door and we glimpse Martin fold into Cory’s arm it closes, shutting us out. Through the door, we hear the man heaving enormous sobs t seem to shake the house’s flimsy foundation. Ben and Jane stand perfectly still, listening to pain ech against the door like a storm. EXT. HANSON HOME -- WIND RIVER, WYOMING -- LATER. Cory and Martin sit on the porch, looking out over the sn covered sagebrush.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I'd like to tell you it gets easier, but it doesn’t. If there’s a comfort -- you get used to the pain if you let yourself ... I went to a grief seminar in Casper. Don’t know why, just ... It hurt so much, I was searching for anything that could make it go away ... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s what I wanted this seminar to do -- make it go away. The instructor come up to me after the seminar was over, sat beside me and said, “I got good news and bad news. Bad news is you'll never be the same. You’1ll never be whole. Ever. What was taken from you can’t be replaced. You’re daughter’s gone. ... Now the good news -- as soon as you accept that, as soon as you let yourself suffer, allow yourself to grieve ... You'll be able to visit her in your mind, and remember all the joy she gave you. All the love she knew. Right now, you don’t even have that, do you?” Martin finds himself shaking his head ‘no’, even though t question wasn’t directed at him.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He said, “that’s what not accepting this will rob from you”. Cory looks at Martin.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you shy from the pain of it, then you rob yourself of every memory of her, my friend. Every one. From her first step to her last smile. You’1l kill ‘em all. Cory puts his hand on Martin’s neck, guides his eyes up t him. CORY (CONT’D) Take the pain ... Take the pain, Martin. It’s the only way to keep her with you. Martin drops his head into his lap. Cory resists the temptation to do the same. The big man stands up, pulls a cigarette from his pocket, lights it. Walks out into the snow.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'm tired, Cory. I’m just so tired of fighting this life.  Ds.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What you do now you do for your son.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Drugs is his family now ... He’s gone too. Lives just down the damn road, but ... He’s gone. Martin takes a long drag.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I expect they’1l find he’s involved in this somehow. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: He stays with the Littlefeather boys, doesn’t he.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yep ... You’re driving this Fed around so she don’t get lost, that it?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That’s what they asked me to do, but that’s not what I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Martin looks back at Cory.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I’m a hunter. What do you think I’m doing? Martin walks toward the porch, bores his hawk eyes into h old friend.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If you find who did this ... (His eyes burn into Cory) No matter who it is. You understand me? He does.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Right where they stand. Martin nods. Flicks his cigarette into the snow.  D4.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Then get off my porch and go do it. Cory stands and follows Martin as he heads back into his crumbling house. INT. CORY’S PICK UP -- DAY. Cory follows Jane’s SUV, who follows Ben’s squad car ... move down an empty highway. As they drive, Cory looks ove sees two coyotes trotting through the snow to his left. Notices a flock of sheep on the horizon... The sheep form their silly circle as the coyotes move clo at a dead run. Cory doesn’t slow down and doesn’t look back. He’s not hunting coyotes. Not today ... EXT. SAM LITTLEFEATHER’S HOUSE -- DAY. The house is the very essence of dilapidation. An old, burgundy MINIVAN that can’t possibly run, sits beside a lowered TOYOTA TERCEL in the driveway. HIP-HOP pulses the windows of the flimsy house. Cory, Jane, and Ben pull off the road. Get out. Cory look down -- sees snow-filled SNOWMOBILE TRACKS beside the highway. They disappear abruptly -- as though they levita Or were loaded onto a trailer ... Cory begins walking through the snow to the back of the h as Jane and Ben head to the front door. Ben draws his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Natalie’s brother lives here with Sam and Bart Littlefeather and a real piece of work named Frank Walker. Hanson’s kid is bad -- but the others are stone evil. Watch yourself.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Should we maybe wait for some back- up?  DD.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: This ain’t the land of back-up, Jane. This is the land of you’re on your own. Jane shakes her head and nods at the same time. Draws her pistol. Ben pounds on the door. They wait for an answer. EXT. LITTLEFEATHER HOUSE -- BACKYARD -- CONT. CORY WALKS THROUGH THE SNOW. He stares at the ground, loo for anything that tells a story. Notices SNOWMOBILE TRACK almost completely filled in with fresh snow, that run wes into the mountains, disappearing into the black timber. He stares at the tracks. Mumbles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Who goes into the mountains just before a storm ... EXT. SAM LITTLEFIELD’S HOUSE -- CONT. Jane and Ben still stand outside the door. Ben knocks aga hard enough to knock the flimsy door through the frame. The music shuts off. Feet move toward the door. It opens. SAM LITTLEFEATHER is 20, tall, and rail thin. His shaved is covered in a RAIDER’S SKULL CAP. His wild eyes fueled three day’s worth of meth. He nods and bounces in place.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Looking for Chip Hanson. He around? Sam shakes his head for an eternity.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Not here, brah.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?  Do.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m the FBI, dickhead. You Sam? He stares at her a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Are you high right now Sam -- how many times have I arrested you? He stares his tweaked eyes at Ben. A flicker of recogniti

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: «+. Chief, wazzup Brah.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Your brother here?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He’s in prison. Where you put him.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No parole? Look at that, the justice system at work. Sam's wild eyes bore into Ben.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Reminds me, I’m supposed to give you this from my P.O. ... Hold on, got it in here somewhere, yeah here it is -- He fishes a small canister of pepper spray from his coat pocket and empties it into their faces. Ben and Jane fall back, coughing and rubbing furiously at their eyes. The door closes. Frantic footsteps and yellin come from the house as Ben and Jane stumble into the snow gasping for breath. EXT. LITTLEFEATHER HOUSE -- BACKYARD -- CONT. Cory hears the shouting and coughing. Ben yells a warning him, then -- FOOTSTEPS moving through the house toward th back door. Cory runs toward it, picking up a SNOW SHOVEL the way ... He brings the shovel up, plants his foot, and swings like hell as the back door opens -- a FAT TEENAGER DRESSED LIK GANGSTER runs right into the meat of the shovel. He is blown back into the door frame, and into CHIP HANS 21, the boy from the photos on Martin Hanson’s wall. Chip falls over the fat one, landing hard in the snow FACE FIR He rolls over and sees: FROM CHIP’S POV -- We are looking up at Cory -- AND HIS BOOT -- coming towar us. Fast. Blocking the sun like an eclipse. Slamming us b into the snow. EXT. LITTLEFEATHER HOUSE -- FRONT DOOR -- CONT. Jane forces herself to stand, snot and tears running free down her face. Ben is struggling to stand, fighting the liquid cayenne pepper wreaking havoc on his senses. He stumbles to the ground, vomiting and cursing simultaneously. Jane sneezes and spits mucus as she raises her pistol eye level and enters the house ... INT. LITTLEFEATHER HOUSE -- CONT. It is dark. No electricity. A small fire burns in an oil in the living room -- smoke escaping through a hole in th roof. WE RUN BEHIND HER, LOOKING OVER HER SHOULDER. She stumbles, sneezes, and trips over the ocean of trash the floor. Notices the open back door and Cory, standing the two teens sprawled in the snow. She motions for him to stay there and moves deeper into t house. She hears the sounds of shells being fed into a shotgun, hears a round pumped into the chamber. She stumbles through the ankle-high trash and falls again the wall, announcing her presence. She strains to see thr her tears. A BLACK BLUR MOVES INTO THE HALLWAY. She fires round after round in its direction. The muzzle flash of her pistol blinds us -- the echo of the rounds b into our skull. RINGING IS ALL WE CAN HEAR.  Do. She stumbles further down the hall. Sees Sam crumpled on floor -- a shotgun beside him. A bullet has pierced his cheek, another his neck. Goose d protrudes from holes in his coat. Blood pumps from his ne to the rhythm of his dying heart. He looks up at her -- face filled with surprise and hate. tries to say something, but no sound comes. THE RINGING FADES, REPLACED WITH JANE’S LABORED BREATHING She leans against the wall. Hears Ben kicking through the trash behind her. She looks back down -- Sam is trying to grab the shotgun -- piece of shit to the very last. She reaches down, grabs the shotgun. Steps away, still pointing her pistol at him.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: The other two’s outside with Cory. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He’s alive, Ben. We need to call EMS.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: EMS is an hour away. Leave him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He’s not dead, Ben. Ben walks up to Sam, looks down. Sam’s wild, wired eyes s back. He gulps for air once, twice ... There is no third time.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Like I said. Let’s go. They walk out of frame, leaving us with Sam’s lifeless bo on the floor -- beer cans, fast food containers, and filt clothes scattered around him. EXT. LITTLEFEATHER HOUSE -- BACKYARD -- CONT. When Jane and Ben step out, they see two young men hog-ti with bailing wire, face down in the snow. Cory leans against a small tool shed, holding his revolve

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Skinny one’s Natalie’s brother.  Dy.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Who’s the other one?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: That’s Frank Walker.(To Frank) Won’t your daddy be proud?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: My dad’s in prison, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I know, I put him there. Prison’1l be good for you, Frank. Get you on your dad’s exercise plan -- lifting weights and selling hand jobs for cigarettes. Slim you right up. You'll come out of there looking like Johnny Depp, I bet.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Tell me what happened to your sister, Chip.

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: What? What happened to her.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Don’t play dumb.

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: About what? What happened to her? Jane and Ben look at him. Is he a criminal and a drug add Yes. Is he a liar? Sure. Is he lying now -- not a chance. CHIP (CONT’D) What did those crackers do? No one speaks. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What crackers? Was she seeing a white man? Do you know him -- do you know who he is?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Do you know his name, Chip?

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: «++. You said was. Why did you say was? (Chip looks up at Cory) What happened. Why did she say was? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ou.

dialogues.speaker: CHIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She just said was -- why did she say was? Cory stands up, walks over to him. Kneels close. Speaks softly as he points toward the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Because I found her raped and killed right over there, son. That’s why. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: «+. WHAAATTTT????? From across the frozen plains, we look at Sam Littlefeath house -- smoke rising through a hole in the roof. Chip’s screams carrying across the white desert -- or perhaps it the wind howling. In this place they sound the same. EXT. LITTLEFEATHER HOUSE -- LATER. Again -- an ambulance and police vehicles. Officers mill about out front. Chip and Frank sit cuffed in the back of separate cars. Cory is unloading his snowmobile off the trailer. Jane is pulling on coveralls emblazoned with the BIA POLICE SEAL. She walks up to Cory, who straps a gun case into a rifle on the front of his snowmobile. Straps a HEAVY DUFFEL BAG SNOWSHOES to the back.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You go. I’m going to get Chip to Lander. See if he’ll give me a name for this boyfriend. He’s who we need to find.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: This is how we find him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No. We go to where he works or where he lives, (Pointing to the mountains) not out there.
