dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Okay, where’s he live? Where’s he work? What’s his name. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that piece of shit’s gonna tell you? You keep looking for clues, and missing all the signs. You see that? He points out over the snow. ol.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don’t -- no. I don’t see anything. He shakes his head as he pulls a pair of binoculars from duffel.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Look there. She takes the binoculars. Looks through them.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Where? He stands behind her, wraps his arm around her, and point out over the snow.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You see my arm through the binocs?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That’s all I can see.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: When I move my hand, look where it was ... You see the tracks? a sled track, filled with snow ... Look for the shadow in it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Now look straight out -- at the base of the mountains, you'll see it easy there. In the distance, the slight indentation stands out. The tracks run straight from the house up into the pine trees that cover the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes ... I see it. She looks up at him.  oz.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Natalie died over there -- seven miles(He points north). Those tracks lead to the mountain from here -- that’s five miles. He points south to tall drill rigs jutting up from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s West-Central’s nearest rigs. Six miles. Someone unloaded sleds right here and drove way the hell out there, but there’s no tracks coming back -- why is that? (Cory points at the house) Do those assholes look like they’re up for a trek ten miles into the snow? In what -- that minivan? The answers are out there. It’s hard to say whether she doesn’t buy what he’s saying just dreads going into the mountains. She comes clean.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Look ... I’ve never done this before, okay? He nods. Appreciates the honesty.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: It’s all I’ve ever done.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Reluctantly) Okay. Let’s go. Cory gets on, fires it up. Pulls a TWO-WAY RADIO from his coveralls, clips it to the front. Jane climbs on and Cory pulls around to the back of the house. TWO OFFICERS are lining the house with police tape. Ben s from the house.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What channel you running?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Eleven. Cory tunes his radio to eleven.  os.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to see you back here by nightfall -- gives you three hours at best.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I'll radio if we come across anything. He guns his sled and they shoot off over the snow. EXT. WYOMING PLAINS -- LATER. WE ARE FLYING OVER THE SNOW -- ALARMINGLY FAST. Again, Ja finds herself pasted to Cory’s back -- hiding from the sn that pelts every exposed part of her. The forest looms over us. We are climbing now. Trees begi whipping past us. Cory doesn’t slow down. We are moving almost vertically up the mountain -- the en whines angrily as the snowmobile lurches uphill, digging into the snow then firing out of it like a rocket. They reach a bench -- a level area that cuts into the mountain. Cory stops. Cuts the engine, it is instantly silent. Jane dares to look up and is shocked to find the valley f a thousand feet below them. Cory steps off -- pulling the stainless steel rifle from case, and levering a round into the chamber. He speaks softly, aware they are both hunter and hunted o here.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: The tracks move south from here.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Whispering) What are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Gonna go it on foot for a bit. Not what she wanted to hear. Cory pulls the snowshoes free, tosses a pair to her.  o4.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Step into ‘em, then ratchet the strap down till they’re good and tight. She does. His are already on by the time she’s strapped o foot in. She steps into the other.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Follow me. They walk through the soft, deep snow of the mountains. The snowmobile tracks cut west, away from the valley into even deeper timber. They follow. Jane pants heavily -- she is in snow to her waist. It is grueling work to take even one step, though you wouldn’t it from watching Cory, who is pulling away from her. She labors forward, looks up at a clump of Aspens and Pin Looks back down, unable to see her feet through the snow. When she looks up again, the clump of trees silently come life, the trunks melting into one giant mass that is walk toward the clearing. She freezes. IT IS A BULL MOOSE stepping through the snow, making no sound. It stands almost eight feet tall, and it is lookin right at her. She feels Cory step quietly beside her.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Whispers) What the fuck is that.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (Quiet) Moose, stay still. He don’t want any more trouble than you do.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don’t want ANY.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Then you two have something in common.  oD. The enormous creature moves across the ‘road’ and the bar visible tracks they follow. It is twenty feet from them, still makes no sound. It slinks into the trees across the road and is enveloped the forest -- disappearing as quickly as it appeared. Jane's tries to gasp in a silent breath of much needed ai Cory can’t help but smile.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah ... Come to Florida, sport. We have alligators on our golf courses.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I’1l stick to the world I know. Cory starts moving off. Jane gathers her strength and follows. CROWS can be heard cawing. The trail opens to a clearing, snow here is so deep, there is no evidence of any tracks. But at the far end of the clearing, A DOZEN CROWS gather around a DEAD SOMETHING. Cory moves toward it, trudging through the snow. The crow scream their frustration at having their dinner interrupt As Cory and Jane get closer, they relent and fly to nearb branches. They stare at the dead animal -- flesh the color of a pee apple. They are almost upon it before they realize it is man.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Cory steps closer. Looks at the body, which is stripped naked. The crows have been busy, as have the other animal of the forest, though his face has been mostly spared. He is young and white.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No. Bet I know who he is though ... Cory nods. Looks around. No snowmobile tracks anywhere. H moves into the forest.  oo.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Stay here. Cory pushes into the timber. Looks at the ground, where s is unable to cover as quickly. He scans the harder snow. Spots Something. Moves to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SNOWMOBILE TRACK -- clear enough to see the tread patte Cory’s face registers surprise. He follows the track a bi The thicker timber opens up to another clearing and the t disappears. He looks up at the sky -- the sun is fading. Looks back a Jane -- no chance she is up for or capable of continuing into the night. He turns back. Jane looks relieved when he reappears from the forest.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: See anything?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: The tracks don’t lead from the house. They lead to it. Someone stripped this boy, left him here and drove down to Littlefeather’s house, loaded their sleds on a trailer and headed down the highway. Jane has no idea how Cory has put this together, but recognizes the truth of it. She looks down. Ashamed. Has laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Are there tracks we can follow?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: For a bit. They went high where the snow’s deeper. Where the tracks would get covered. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I need to get a team up here that has experience with this area. With crimes like these. This was ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was well thought out. She looks over at the man, half-eaten and frozen in the s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number of police vehicles has grown. FREMONT COUNTY SHERIFF’S VEHICLES CAN BE SEEN. NUMEROUS SNOWMOBILES LINE UP, PREPARING TO HEAD OUT. Cory speaks with Ben.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: We went on foot the last half mile, but we blazed a decent trail through the snow ... I’1l run them back up there if you need.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I'll talk to the sheriff, he may want you to. Jane walks up to them.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The security team at West-Central’s rig site has cameras around their perimeter. I’m gonna head over in the morning, maybe we'll get lucky and they caught something on film.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Okay. The two we have in custody say anything?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: These aren’t the talking kind, Jane. These kids -- they expect to go to prison. It’s a rite of passage. Hell, I think they look forward to it. Three hots, a cot, and free cable? Beats being here doing nuthing, the way they see it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Let’s run their DNA against the semen, see what that tells us. Cory looks over at the police car where Chip still sits.  os.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Can I talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Cory, anything they might tell you would be inadmissable in court, and anything you told us would render everything that resulted inadmissable as well.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What if I talked to him and didn’t tell you what he said. I just knew it. Jane's cell phone rings. Answers.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Agent Banner. Yes sir, yes we did. Jane steps away. Cory looks at Ben.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I’ve known him since he was three. Ben can’t say yes. Doesn’t want to say no.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I gotta canvas the house. The back doors are only locked from the inside ... Ben walks off. Cory looks at the squad car. Goes to it. INT. BEN’S POLICE VEHICLE -- NIGHT. Chip sits, shivering. Looks exhausted. Coming down, maybe Maybe just tired from crying. Cory opens the door, sits beside him -- leaves one foot outside so he doesn’t lock himself in the car. Chip looks at him, assumes the hard stare of a criminal.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Look at us.

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: Look at you. I didn’t do shit.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: All you been doing is shit for three years.  oy. Beat. Chip softens.

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: «+. It’s this place. Look what it makes you do. What it takes from us. What it took from you.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I’m not going to sit here and say life’s been fair. To either of us. This land is all we got left. Barely four thousand of us still breathing --

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: What are you -- a fucking quarter Arapaho? Only thing Indian about you is your ex-wife and a daughter you couldn't protect. Maybe if you'd played detective then -- Cory slams his head into the front divider before he can finish the sentence.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You gonna lecture me about protecting our people? Hmm? While you deal the shit that’s killing ‘em? You know what you are -- you're just a ‘hang-around-the- fort’ prairie nigger begging for smallpox blankets you can sell to your friends. That’s what you sell, chief -- the smallpox of your generation. You had every chance to get out if that’s what you wanted. Army. College. It was your choice. And look what you chose. Cory swings open the car door. Gets out.

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: (Small) I met him. Wanted to fight his ass. But he just took everything I said. Not like a coward. Like a man ... She loved him ... He works security on a drill site ... One of those guards, that’s where the smallpox comes from.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What’s the boyfriend’s name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt something ...

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: He the smallpox dealer too?

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: I doubt it. I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Who does? Chip looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: Sam knew. Why don’t you ask him? Cory looks at the criminal that used to be a boy he knew well.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You'll be talking to Sam long before I do, Chip. Of that I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: CHIP
dialogues.text: You think this is who I wanted to be? I just ... I get so mad, I want to fight the whole world. You know what that feels like?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I do. I decided to fight the feeling instead. Know why? Cory leans back into the car.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because I knew the world would win. Cory closes the door. Sees Ben and Jane talking. They loo him as he approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What did I tell you -- Did he say anything -- never mind, don’t tell us. What did he say? Cory’s eyes are steel.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going out to the rigs tomorrow morning? Cory looks at Jane as he leans into Ben. Whispers --

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Natalie’s boyfriend worked there.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What? Don’t tell me -- Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hmm ... This thing is solving itself. We’ll pick him up in the morning and see what he’s got to say.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: We're picking him up now. From three feet of snow --

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Chip said that?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I say that. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: But you don’t know it. I want you with us tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You don’t catch a wolf searching where he might be ... Cory looks out over the snowmobile tracks leading through snow. Shadows fill their slight indentations, and point toward the mountains like an arrow.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You search where he’s been ... and he’s been here. EXT. WILMA LAMBERT’S HOUSE -- NIGHT. Cory stands at the door, his breath frosting in front of Knocks softly. Knows she’ll never hear that, tries a litt louder. A light comes on. The door opens. Wilma stands there in robe. For an instant, she seems worried about how she mus look, then remembers issues far more grave surround them.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I been better.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Brings everything back, doesn’t it.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yeah. She shakes her head. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: You and Ben and this little FBI girl formed your own posse to go solve it all, I hear.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I’m just trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: You won’t get the answers you’re looking for. No matter what you find.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: This isn’t about Em --

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Don’t you say her name. Her venom brings out his.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I didn’t kill her, Wilma.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Yes you did. We both did ... We looked away. We let our guard down, and this place snatched her from us. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have one chance left at this, and I for one will not rest a second until he is grown and living very far from here. Where it’s never cold and your baby doesn’t-- She fights it back. Calms herself. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If doing this gives you some sort of closure, I’m happy for you. Closure for me will be Casey married and happy with a family of his own.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Then what.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: «+. Good night, Cory. She closes the door. EXT. CORY LAMBERT’S HOUSE -- NIGHT. Jane's SUV pulls up as Cory hauls hay into the corral. He tosses it into the trough. Walks toward Jane’s SUV. She rolls down her window.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Matt Rayburn. Did you know him?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That the man in the snow?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: His fingerprints are in the database -- he was enrolled at the Police Academy in Rock Springs. Supposed to begin in April. Worked as a security officer for a drill station out here.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You wanna come in?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. He turns and walks to the house. She shuts down the SUV a follows. INT. CORY LAMBERT’S HOUSE -- A MOMENT LATER. Jane looks around the living room. Spots reloading equipm on the dining room table. The silver-colored rifle lays o towel placed over the coffee table -- stretched out like snake. Her hand goes to her sidearm, checking that it’s still th She sees numerous photos of Casey, and the mini-shrine on mantle. Looks at the girl’s picture.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got milk, coffee, and tap water.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Tap water’s fine. Thanks. She steps closer to the photo.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s my daughter. She turns, caught.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She passed on three years ago. She figured as much, buts feigns surprise anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You wanna ask how, don’t you.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I do ... But I won’t. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I was working as an outfitter out of Pinedale. There was a big snow, and I found myself with a night off, so I grabbed a motel room and told my wife to come up. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just her -- You get precious little romance with two kids and a job that keeps you in the mountains half the year ... Emily was sixteen. Casey was five. You could trust her ... She was a good girl. We lived out on the Rez not far from her parents ... Should’ve made ‘em stay with Wilma’s folks ... I guess word got out that we were out of town and some school friends came over. Then more came over. He looks up at Emily’s photo on the mantle.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then some people came that weren’t her friends. Get together turned into quite a party, and then, I don’t know ... He looks around like he might sit -- might need something lean on to continue. Decides to tell it where he stands.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A lot I don’t want to know ... It was Natalie that called us the next day. Told us Emily was missing. They were best friends, so... Natalie was worried. She had a right to be ... Can’t go any further on his feet. He sits on the couch. J doesn’t move an inch.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You try to be so careful, try to plan for everything. Emily was such a good girl, we just ... let our guard down ... You’ll have kids some day, and let me tell you, Jane: you can’t blink. For eighteen- years. Not once ... Cory swallows the pain. Looks up at his daughter on the mantle. Then to his feet. CORY (CONT’D) Some guy was moving his sheep near Wind River. He’s the one who found her ... Twenty something miles from our house. How she got there? What happened -- I don’t know. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn’t find out much from the autopsy cuz the (he sucks in a pained breath) Coyotes had been at her pretty good. He looks right at her. CORY (CONT’D) And I've been killing those sons of bitches ever since. Jane tries to find something to say -- anything -- but there’s nothing. All she can think to utter is:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Can you point me toward your --

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Yeah, right down the hall. She walks down the hall to the bathroom. Closes herself i Stares at herself in the mirror -- not a decade older tha Natalie was, than Emily would be. Splashes water on her f Leans against the counter, relishing a moment without tension, terror, or heartache. Steels herself and opens t door. She walks out and notices a poem, framed and hanging on t wall. She reads the heading -- A MEADOW IN MY PERFECT WOR She reads the poem. Cory walks up, leans beside her.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She got accepted to a summer program for creative writing at Colorado State. That’s what got her in. Jane looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: She wrote this to you? And for the first time, there is a crack in the steel.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I don’t know who she wrote it to. Beat.  CORY (CONT’D) I like to think it was me. He disappears into the living room. She follows. Stands before him. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what the Hanson boy told you, but I don’t want to stumble into something like today if I can help it. If he told you something I need to know ...

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: He told me one of those guards sells ‘em meth. Which one? I don’t know. Also told me her boyfriend worked security for West-Central.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You could've called for that.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I wanted to know why you’re helping me. What your motivation was. (Gentle) Now I do. Cory smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Didn’t trust me.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Didn’t trust how good you are at it. She works her way to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is it possible to not drive the snowmobiles eighty-miles an hour tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Sure, if you don’t mind landing in a ditch you could've sailed over.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: «+. Great. She offers him a smile and leaves. Cory returns to the t of making rifle rounds. Places one of the giant bullets o ELECTRONIC SCALE. The reading says: 544 GRAINS. He takes a FILE, expertly shaves the bullet down. Places back on the scale: 540 GRAINS. Perfect. He seats it in the machine, pulls the lever, driving the bullet into the casing. He holds up the round. Studies it This bullet has a home, and Cory is close to finding it. EXT. FREMONT COUNTY SHERIFF'S STATION -- MORNING. Cory pulls into the parking lot, snowmobile in tow. Two TRIBAL POLICE VEHICLES are parked by Jane’s SUV and a SHERIFF'S PICK UP TRUCK, two SHERIFF’S DEPUTIES leaning beside it. ALL HOOKED TO TRAILERS CARRYING SNOWMOBILES. Jane, Ben, two BIA POLICE, and two SHERIFF’S DEPUTIES -- and EVAN, stand in a circle bouncing in place, fighting o the cold, their breath rising from their mouths like smok Cory steps out. Walks to them.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It’s a cold one today. Cory barely notices.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Below zero, I bet.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Six below. (Points to the mountains) Colder out there. Cory studies him.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You're shaking worse than her. Looking at Jane, that’s debatable. Evan walks up to Cory.

dialogues.speaker: EVAN
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, bud?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: In case you wander off, I’m here to track you down. Evan laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard from a reliable source one of West-Central’s security officers may be supplying meth on the Rez, we don’t know which one --

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: The nervous one. They all chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Eyes peeled is the point. Everyone ready? They move to their cars. Jane looks at Cory.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: If you find anything, radio us.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I will. You do the same. She offers him a smile. It isn’t returned -- he is a hunt today, no room for anything else... Everyone moves to their vehicles as the sun crests the mountains, kissing the land that surrounds them. EXT. HIGHWAY 789 -- DAY. The procession moves down the empty highway. WE MOVE ABOVE THEM -- PULLING AWAY. The land is white in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: MERE SPECS BELOW US.
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE --— Sitting low beside the highway, frostbitten sagebrush blo in and out of view -- we hear the vehicles approaching. Rubber attacking road. Whining. Humming. Louder. Nothing sounded less natural ... The vehicles race past us in a blur, snow swirling in the wake.  ou. EXT. HIGHWAY -- CONT. Cory pulls surrounded snowmobile highway. He puts on road fades over in front of Sam Littlefeather’s place, now in YELLOW POLICE TAPE. He begins unstrapping his as the other vehicles push farther down the his white camo as the whine of rubber on frozen into the distance. EXT. HIGHWAY 789 -- DAY. WE PULL OVER. STOP. EVERYONE GETS OUT. In the dis miles away Snowmobile are starte She looks She climbs He rises oj sits on th tance, DRILL RIGS and TRAILERS can be seen. Though , they stand out like blisters in this white world. s are unloaded and mounted. Engines scream as they d. Ben fires his snowmobile, looks back at Jane.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Get on. at him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Getting really tired of these things.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. You’re a Florida girl, right? Just like those jet-skis, ain't it? on behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If there was an easier way to travel snow, we'd be doing it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Let’s get it over with. (Looks at her bare hands) Shit. Forgot to bring gloves ... You mind? ut of the seat. She places her hands down and he em. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: See? All sorts of perks to this deal.  OL.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: «+. Yeah. She tries not to, but can’t help smiling either. All six snowmobiles take off toward the rigs, blowing smo and spitting snow. EXT. -- WEST-CENTRAL DRILL STATION, TWENTY-TWO -- DAY. A DOZEN DRILLS rise from the earth. ENORMOUS GALVANIZED PIPING undulates above and below the snow, like a steel serpent. TELEPHONE POLES have been sunk every thirty feet. WIRES c cross from them. His foot prevents her.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: My God, the women out here are spunky. He raises his pistol. Something catches his eye. He looks Sees something. He squints -- it appears the snow itself is standing to f him. The muzzle flash from Cory’s rifle shoots five-feet out t barrel. The bullet punches a hole in Curtis’s chest we can almost through. Punches a hole through the trailer behind him. Curtis is thrown back into the trailer, dead before he le his feet. Jane rolls over and crawls underneath the trailer. The one security guard who still stands looks out over th plains. Sees nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY OFFICER
dialogues.text: You see where that came from?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (Shouting from the trailer) No! The security officer strains to see. Looks to his friend, bleeding in the snow.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY OFFICER
dialogues.text: Can you stand up?

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY OFFICER 2
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY OFFICER
dialogues.text: Well, you better figure it out, cuz we're not done. The wounded man struggles to his feet. Dizzy. He looks ou over the plains. Turns back and sees -- Cory, standing fi yards from him.  LUZ. The security guard doesn’t even have the presence of mind raise his pistol, just points his finger in Cory’s direct Cory has fired and ejected the second round before the fi one hits the ground. Both men are thrown backward into th snow. The men in the trailer return fire, but Cory is gone. INT. MATT’S TRAILER -- WEST-CENTRAL STATION -- CONT. Pete and a security officer peer out through the window.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY OFFICER 3
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY OFFICER 3
dialogues.text: He went behind trailer three --

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Curtis! Mike! Curtis!

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY OFFICER 3
dialogues.text: (Drawing calming breaths) Okay, okay ... Cory’s bullet punches through the trailer, through the si through the security guard and through the wall behind hi knocking a six inch hole that bleeds light into the room. The man is pulled backward in the bullet’s wake, falling on the floor. Pete drops to the floor, crawls to the bedroom. He climbs over the bed and kicks out the window. Climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE. Under the trailer. She empties her gun at Pete as he runs. They punch into h Kevlar Vest, and knock him to the ground. He stands immediately and continues running. She rolls on her back, shivers. Cory kneels down -- offers her a hand. She takes it. Pull her out.  Lus.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: How bad are you hit?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (Through chattering teeth) I don’t know. Cory helps her to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I gotta get you in this trailer. He lifts her up, and carries her inside. INT. MATT’S TRAILER -- WEST-CENTRAL STATION -- CONT. Cory sets her on a couch. Heads to the bedroom, returns w the bedding. Wraps it around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I need to have a look. She nods and he unzips the coveralls, runs his hand insid Pulls it out, looks at it -- no blood. Runs his hand alon her sides, her belly, feels something warm. Looks at his hand -- blood, but not an alarming amount.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think a few rounds got through, but only in pieces. You’re not bleeding too bad. He looks at her neck, this wound is more severe.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This one ain’t great. He takes some of the sheet. Presses it against the wound.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold that there. She does. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Give me your radio. (He doesn’t) My best chance is a helicopter flying me out of here, you don’t have one of those, do you?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No.  Lua.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Give me your radio.(He does) Go get him.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I won’t bring him back, Jane. You need to know that. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I do. Go get him. She gives the tiniest of nods. He stands up and walks out EXT. WIND RIVER MOUNTAINS -- DAY. WE RUN THROUGH THE SNOW. We stumble. Breathe heavy. Stand and continue. We hear the whine of an engine in the distance. It echoes through the trees -- no way to know where it comes from.

dialogues.speaker: WE LOOK AT PETE, STANDING IN THE SNOW, TREES ALL AROUND H
dialogues.text: He turns in every direction, trying to pinpoint the sound the machine echoing through the mountains. The sound stops. The forest is silent. Pete pulls a pisto from its holster, and continues marching through the froz forest. He freezes. Hears something -- a gnawing sound. He turns. A PORCUPINE IS CLIMBING A NAKED ASPEN TREE. It chews the bark. Stops. Looks at Pete -- like any anima the porcupine can sense the hunted. Can smell the fear. T porcupine’s button eyes show no sympathy -- better you th me. When Pete turns he finds CORY STANDING IN FRONT OF HIM. Pete screams like a startled child. The butt of Cory’s ri slams into Pete’s chin, knocking him backward. EXT. GANNET PEAK -- WIND RIVER MOUNTAINS -- DAY. The sun sits low in the Western sky. We are well above th treeline. Ragged mountains cut the skyline in every direction.  Lud. Pete lays in the snow, blindfolded. Hands bound. The blindfold is ripped off. His hands cut free. Cory stands over him.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Know where you are?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: «+. No. Pete shivers in the snow, his breath crystallizing the instant it’s exhaled.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That’s Gannet Peak. Highest mountain in Wyoming. We look around. Deep in the land of nothing. Only bitter cold. CORY (CONT’D) On the hottest day in August there’s a foot of snow. Today ... Cory looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s too cold to snow.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Okay ... Okay ... Let’s just -- let’s talk for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Alright. Pete’s teeth chatter -- he looks down at his feet -- NO SHOES.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Wha -- WHAT THE FUCK!? (Sobs) -- what the, what --

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I give you a minute and this is how you spend it -- cussing and crying?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Listen, okay ... I’ve made mistakes. I’ve ... I’ve ...  Luo.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What. What did you do. I’m not a policeman -- tell me the truth and I'll give you a chance.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Alright. Just ... You know what it’s like? Stuck out in this frozen hell -- nothing to do? No nothing. No women, no fun? Just fucking ... snow and silence.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: My people have been stuck in this shit for a century. Snow and silence is the only thing that hasn’t been taken from us ... You took from us too, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I don’t -- how did I --

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You have a little taste, did you? Got lonely ... Got drunk? Beat. CORY (CONT’D) Then what did you get? Pete can barely speak, he is shivering so hard. CORY (CONT’D) If you did it, be a man and say it. Say ‘I raped her’.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: ... I raped her. Cory nods.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Now say, ‘her boyfriend tried to stop me, and we beat him to death.’ He nods. CORY (CONT’D) Nod won't cut it. Not today. Say it.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We-we-we d-d- we beat him.  LU/.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Fair enough. Cory stands. Grabs his rifle. Slings it over his shoulder

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Wha -- wha -- where.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You get the same chance she got.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: What did she -- what did she get?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Stand up big boy. I’m a man of my word. If you can make it to the highway, you’re a free man. Pete stands up. Looks around -- they are so deep in the mountains, so high up, the valley isn’t even visible.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Where -- where’s the highway? He looks at Cory, eyes wide.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You know how far it is from that drill camp to where Natalie was found -- almost six miles. Barefoot. That’s a warrior. (Looks the freezing man over) I doubt you'll make it six hundred feet. Still, we should make this fair ... Cory walks up pulling a large hunting knife from its shea and slices Pete’s parka open down the middle.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There we go.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. What do you want me to do? Cory steps close to him.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I want you to run.  LUO. Cory places the muzzle of his rifle beside Pete’s ear. Pu the trigger. The gun is so loud, we expect the mountain to collapse. Instead, it is only Pete’s eardrum that erupts. Pete scre as blood funnels out of it. He covers his ear and runs li his life depends on it -- which it does. Cory pulls a ski mask over his face, climbs on his snowmo and goes after him. Pete runs -- bare feet slamming into snow. He screams, lo for a way down the steep mountain, sees none. Looks back, Cory is right behind him. He runs faster, arms flinging wildly. Suddenly, half of h disappears -- THE SNOW IS SO DEEP IT COVERS HIM TO HIS WAIST. Pete looks back at Cory, who fires a round right over his head. He shrieks in terror and pushes further into the sn He breathes harder, deeper. As he exhales, a thin mist of blood spews out. Cory slows down, let’s Pete get distance, gives him hope. WE WATCH PETE FADE INTO THE MOUNTAIN -- The man becoming speck in a world of white. Pete FUMBLES, weak -- blood is frozen to the side of his face. Cory stops. Watches him. Seconds ache by. Sees him slow d stumble, then fall. He doesn’t get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete lays in the snow, coughing -- gasping -- freezing fr the inside out. He rolls on his back. The sky is so close can almost reach out and touch it. He reaches his arm up, stretching. Stays like this. No breath. No movement. He is gone. Cory turns the snowmobile east and begins the long ride h INT. FREMONT COUNTY HOSPITAL -- NIGHT. Jane lays in a hospital bed, IV tubes running to and from her.  Luy. She stares at the ceiling, too tired to cry but knowing i coming. She feels a presence. Looks to the door. Cory sta there.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You made it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: So did you.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I bet this ain’t how they sell those bulletproof vests in the brochure, is it? She chuckles, and pain runs through her body.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Don’t make me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Shouldn't joke. It saved your life.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You're a tough girl, Jane. You saved your own life.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Let’s be honest, I just got lucky. He sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Luck don’t live out here. Luck lives in the city. Whether someone runs the stoplight, whether your bank’s the one that gets robbed, whether someone’s dialing their cellphone when they come to a crosswalk ... Luck is winning or losing. Out here, you survive or you surrender. That’s determined by your strength. You spirit. Wolves don’t kill unlucky deer, they kill weak ones. He leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You fought for your life. And now you get to leave with it.  Liv. He sits back. Stretches his legs out, gets comfortable. S realizes why he’s here -- and it wasn’t to make sure she’ alright. It’s to watch over her until she’s able to watch over herself. He reaches into a stack of magazines, grabs one. Flips through it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I know what you're doing. But she doesn’t object.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I'll read something to you ... “How to know if he’s into you -- ten signs. Number one: he looks you in the eye when he speaks.” You’re supposed to do that anyway, ain’t you. I don’t think that one’s reliable ... She can’t help but laugh, can’t help but be moved by the gesture. But laughter brings pain, and thoughts of the da and all she saw ... All she endured. Laughter turns to te She fights them at first, but Cory’s hand finds hers. Squeezes, unleashing all she’s fought to contain. She cries like it’s her first time to do so, purging the demons that ravage her mind and heart. He is neither uncomfortable nor surprised. He knew she needed this. We watch her sob as he stretches over the hospital bed, caressing her battered hand. EXT. BULL LAKE -- WIND RIVER INDIAN RESERVATION -- DAY. We look out over a frozen lake. Dead center of it is a sm bright green ICE FISHING HUT. A SNOWMOBILE parked beside We PUSH toward it. INT. ICE FISHING HUT -- CONT. Cory and Casey sit on little stools, holding fishing pole Their lines disappears into a 12 inch hole cut into the i They stare at the hole.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You want your sandwich?  dite

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: No. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I have some of your coffee?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No. They say it’1l stunt your growth.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: ... What’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: It’ll make you short. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: I’m already short.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Not as short as you'll be if you drink coffee. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Do you like ice fishing?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Not really. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Wanna do something else? Casey thinks about that.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY
dialogues.text: Nah ... Don’t matter what we do, so long as we're doing it, you know what I mean? Cory looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I do.  Liz. Casey smiles then looks down to the hole in the ice, neve knowing what those words meant to his father. But, if he to look up and into his eyes -- as we do now -- he would begin to understand. EXT. BULL LAKE -- WIND RIVER INDIAN RESERVATION -- CONT. WE PULL AWAY FROM THE HUT. As we back away, the white world dominates our view in ev direction. We RISE. High above the lake, watching the green hut shri the only thing in this place that dares to defy the color winter. THE END.
